archimate:ArchimateDiagramModel.name: Sercurity Architecture
archimate:ArchimateDiagramModel.documentation:
Security Architecture is a comprehensive structure of organizational, conceptual, logical, and physical components that work together to manage risk across the enterprise. It ensures secure, safe, resilient, reliable, and privacy-respecting behavior throughout the organization.
It is not isolated, but integrated with all other architecture elements, forming a cohesive part of the overall enterprise architecture.
Key Elements: Risk Management: Focuses on both business risk and operational risk, aiming to minimize negative consequences and maximize opportunities.
Business-Driven Approach: Business objectives drive the context for risk assessment and dictate the need for security controls and compliance.
Systems Engineering Integration: Security is embedded early in the system development lifecycle, with relevant activities in every phase—from early guidance to final security checks.
Operational Monitoring: In the operational phase, security is continuously monitored, assessed, and reported, particularly addressed in TOGAF ADM Phases G and H.
Enterprise-Level Focus: The term “Enterprise Security Architecture” implies alignment with enterprise-wide business goals, rather than local or isolated areas.
The TOGAF definition of “enterprise” spans a broad scope—from departments to entire corporations or government agencies.
Security Architecture Outputs: Relationships across architecture layers are defined to provide traceability and justification for security decisions.
Developed using Information Security Management (ISM) and Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) practices.
Delivered in coordination with key business and technical stakeholders.
